pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.10: “Venerable Ajjuka is not a monastic anymore.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.13: On that occasion Venerable Upāli was siding with Ajjuka,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.15: “Ānanda, when one is asked by the owner to assign a property to so-and-so and one does as asked, what has one committed?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.16: “One hasn’t committed anything, Sir, not even an act of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.17: “Venerable Ajjuka was asked by the owner to assign his property to so-and-so, which he did.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.18: There’s no offense for Venerable Ajjuka.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.1: At that time a family in Benares that supported Venerable Pilindavaccha was harassed by criminals.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.2: Two of their children were kidnapped.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.3: Soon afterwards Pilindavaccha brought those children back by his supernormal powers and put them in a stilt house.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.4: When people saw those children, they said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.5: “This is the greatness of Venerable Pilindavaccha’s supernormal powers,”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.6: and they gained confidence in him.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.7: But the monks complained and criticized him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.8: “How could Venerable Pilindavaccha bring back children who had been kidnapped by criminals?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.10: “There’s no offense for someone who uses their supernormal powers.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.1: At that time the two monks Paṇḍaka and Kapila were friends.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.2: One was staying in a village and one at Kosambī.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.3: Then, while one of them was traveling from that village to Kosambī, he had to cross a river. As he did so, a lump of fat that had escaped from the hands of a pork-butcher stuck to his foot.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.4: He grabbed it, thinking, “I’ll give it to the owners.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.5: But the owners accused him, saying,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.7: Just then a woman cowherd who had seen him crossing said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.9: Thinking he was no longer a monastic, he had sexual intercourse with her.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.10: When he arrived at Kosambī, he told the monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.11: who in turn told the Buddha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.12: “There’s no offense entailing expulsion for stealing,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.13: but there’s an offense entailing expulsion for having sexual intercourse.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.49.1: At that time a monk at Sāgalā who was a student of Venerable Daḷhika was plagued by lust. He stole a turban from a shopkeeper and said to Daḷhika,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.49.2: “Sir, I’m not a monastic anymore. I’ll disrobe.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.49.5: Venerable Daḷhika had the turban brought and valued.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.49.6: It was worth less than five _māsaka_ coins.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.49.10: The second offense entailing expulsion is finished.
